results.title: The Red pony
results.creator_credit: Lewis Milestone and Charles K Felman Group
results.brief_description: John Steinbeck’s classic is brought to life with an outstanding cast and a fine script. It is a tender, moving story about the conflict between a nine year old boy, his father and the family’s hired hand. A small red pony becomes the focal point of the complex human relationships at the ranch and is the catalyst for the boy’s growth into manhood. Starring Myrna Loy and Robert Mitchum.

results.title: The Red planet, Mars
results.creator_credit: John Dooley, International Film Bureau and Plymouth Productions
results.brief_description: Reviews the available knowledge of Mars, discussing the information gained from the Mariner IV probe in relation to surface and atmospheric conditions, temperatures, seasonal changes and possible life.

results.title: The Red kite
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A tale taken from a collection of short stories by Canadian author Hugh Hood. The setting is Montreal, and the story simply about a red kite that a man buys for his young daughter. This mildly impulsive act leads to encounters with strangers that cause him to wonder about the whole purpose and meaning of life. The bitter-sweet mood of the film and the setting, Montreal in late summer, creates a strangely haunting view of the city and of time.

results.title: The Red desert = Il deserto rosso
results.brief_description: Guiliana (Monica Vitti) struggles to fit back into her life after suffering from a mental breakdown. Her husband doesn’t seem to be able to help her yet she is drawn to Corrado Zeller (Richard Harris). “Il deserto rosso” is Antonioni’s first colour film and he uses colour, landscape and sound masterfully to reflect Guiliana’s state of mind. Ravenna is transformed into an industrial landscape yet Antonioni manages to make it beautiful by framing objects so that they appear as abstract paintings. Monica Vitti is rivetting as the fragile Guiliana. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: The Red dawn
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “History in action”.
In November 1920, the last of the White Army was evacuated which signalled the end of ‘Old Russia’. Millions died and millions were homeless. Industry was wrecked and farms were ruined, but Lenin, leader of the Bolsheviks was able to retain his power through the use of propaganda, charismatic leadership and where necessary, force. This episode focuses on the abdication of Tsar Nicholas and the gaining of power by the Bolsheviks, and includes archival footage.

results.title: The Red carpet
results.brief_description: When the red carpet is rolled out at the Hotel Bellevue in preparation for the arrival of the Duke of Sultana, it just keeps on rolling. Happy, lively music, continuous action, and a humorous, rhyming text keeps pace with the carpet as it criss-crosses the town and finally arrives at the ferry, just in time for the Duke’s arrival. Good for language development. Based on the book of the sane name by Rex Parkin, published in 1948. Suitable for children aged 4-8.

results.title: The Red balloon. The Little princess
results.creator_credit: Walter Lang, Albert Lamorisse, Gene Markey, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Films Montsouris
results.brief_description: Two children’s classics have been brought together on this one video. “The Red balloon” won many major awards on its release in 1956. A lonely French boy amazingly becomes friends with a red balloon which follows him to school and protects him in the streets of Paris. An absorbing and quite perfect fantasy. Shirley Temple stars in “The Little princess”, which is adapted from Frances Hodgson Burnett’s tale of an orphan girl who loses her father in the Boer war but has faith that he is still alive. Without ever giving up hope and with a little help from the queen she is finally reunited with him. Songs, dances and a spectacular dream sequence are some of the highlights of this 1939 colour film.
